title: WP2: Learning Web-service Domain Ontologies

author: Miha Grčar, Department of Knowledge Technologies, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: Hello everybody, my name is Mr Gotcher from user Stephen Institute and I will be talking about learning web service domain ontologies.
This is the.
This is work we are doing in the context of the European project.
Tau Tau stands for transitioning applications to ontologies.
So first I will tell you what the goal of our work package on this project is.
Then I will give some introduction to application mining.
So what is application mining?
Then I will tell you how we are creating document networks and how we are then later transforming them into feature vectors.
And then I will present to.
Software packages, the first one is Latino, which stands for Link analysis and text mining toolbox.
And the second one is on to Jane, which is a system for semi automatic data driven ontology construction.
I will then say a few words about this whole case study.
And then I will conclude this presentation.
OK, So what is the goal of work package of our work package all about.

So the goal is to facilitate the acquisition of domain ontologies from Legacy applications by first identifying data sources that contain knowledge to be transitioned into an ontology and then employing data mining techniques to 8 the domain expert in building the domain ontology.
So.
Becausw we want to transition.
So because we want to be able to include into this transitioning process nearly any application.
We came up with this term application mining and this is how we see this.
So we can have several cases.
So application can be a regular web service maybe or some C++ Java source code, or maybe your relational database or something else.
And we first convert each and every case into some kind of intermediate data representation, simply because we want our ontology learning algorithms to work for all these cases.
And So what is this intermediate data representation?
It's basically it is partly part of.
It is structured data which are networks and part of it is unstructured data which are textual documents.
And structured data is suitable for link analysis, while the unstructured data is suitable for text mining.
So basically we are talking about document networks which basically each document network is simply a set of interlinked documents and each link in this network has a type and weight.
So I will now present some basic principles of how we do application mining on the gate case study.
So Gate Gate is actually software library for natural language processing.
It contains of roughly 600 Java classes.

They are of three kinds, so they can be arranged into three categories like the first one is language resources, which is the data processing resources which are the algorithms and graphical user interfaces are the third category.
So the this library was developed at University of Sheffield and is freely available at this address.
Um so.
Along with gate.
So in the context of gate, there are several data sources available, some of them are structured, some of them are unstructured.
The structured data sources are, for example, the code samples.
The service usage logs, so the execution logs the source code itself, the reference manual maybe with those from the web service and so on, and the unstructured data sources are web pages.
The users manual, tutorials, lectures and forums newsgroups and so on.
So we will be mainly using the source code.
And this means that we will also be using the reference manual becausw in many as it is common in Java.
Software libraries the reference manual is generated automatically out of source code comments by using the documentation tools such as javadoc.
So this is a typical Java class.
This is one of the gate classes a class has a name.
His name can have several fields, several methods.
Each field has a name.
Each method has a name.
So this green text are the comments.
This is the class comment field comment the method comment.
We can see that in these comments there are.
We can we can see some references to other Java classes and recall such references.
Comment references.
We can see that this class inherits from some base class and implements an interface.
We can see that each field has a type.
Each method has a return value.
And that's basically a lot of structural information in there.
So the question is, how do we now create a document network out of this?
All this information?
So first we create an instance.
We name it.
After the class, we attach a document to it and we create the.
So we populate this document we create.
We create the content of this document out of the source code comments.
So this green text.
So this is now our instance and with this attached document.
And now we now.
We also include this structural information into account.
So we said there are several comment references in this our little example.
So we simply attach those classes to our instance.
There's also this inheritance and interface implementation links, and we also include these two.
There is also these types.
So parameter types and field types.
We also include this.
And this is.
What we get is a very simple example, but this is a document network.
So this is how a real document network looks like this.
This is a gate comment reference network.
And if we zoom in particular.
We can see that, for example.
This class gazetteer list references this class gazetteer.
Once in the comments or for example, this class with the theory tent references this one gazetteer again two times in its comments.
OK.
So now we want to transform this network or these networks into feature vectors.
So how do we do this?
I will not go into too much details, but in principle what we do is we focus on a particular vertex and we describe it with the neighborhood with its neighborhood.
So those vertices that are closer to the vertex that we are describing have higher weights and the highest weight weight is assigned to the vertex itself.
And basically we do this for every vertex and we get this kind of metrics.
And if we take the roots of these metrics, these are now our future.
Our structural feature vectors.
OK, so this is now our instance and there are several types of different structural information attached to it.
For example, like inheritance and interface implementation and comment references, and so on.
And we just talked about how to convert those into feature vectors.
But we also convert this document that is attached to the instance into a feature vector by using standard text mining techniques.
So removing stopwords, stemming, detecting engrams and computing TF IDF vectors in the end.
OK, what we do next is we concatenate this structural feature vector to get one one single structure feature vector and we also append or concatenate this content feature vector to it.
So we get one single combined feature vector for one instance in the Document Network.
OK, so.
I already mentioned Latino or Latino is stands for Link analysis and tax planning tool box.
This is a software which is being developed in the course of work Package 2.
It mostly contains data preprocessing, machine learning, and data visualization algorithms or capabilities.
Um?
Latino does basically all these steps that I was talking about right now.
And so we end up with a set of feature vectors basically, and what we can do next is, for example, we can load this feature vectors into autogen.
Once again is a system for data driven, semi automatic ontology construction.
It is a sect technology, so it was developed during the Project sect and it is freely available at this provided web address.
So basically what we do is first we have some kind of data source.
For example the source code.
We use Latino to produce a set of feature vectors.
We load those feature vectors into auto gain and we use onto again.
To produce the domain ontology.
So this would be 1 setting.
And I will now show.
Oh you.
Demo of Auto game.
So this is this is aunt again and what I did before hand because it takes some time is I. I visualized the semantic space of the feature vectors I imported.
And right here, what you see here?
So these islands.
So in a way these are feature vectors created out of.
Name name similarity structural information.
So you can see here several dots very close together.
This means that these Java classes have similar names.
OK, and what don't again.
Thus, to create an ontology is actually clustered this instance.
Level by level is I will show you, so we use first disk visualization to kind of count the number of violence and to decide how many concepts we want to identify in this feature space.
For example here we have like.
34567 let's say 8.
Let's say that we want to create 88 first level concepts.
We go to suggestions, increase the number to 8 and we get 88 suggestions.
So eight clusters of instances.
That we can now attach.
So attach to the root concept of our ontology.
So what we got is basically this is now our very simple ontology.
Well, it's not, it's just the taxonomy.
But still and you can, it is possible to see that the the instances.
So the Java classes that are grouped together in this leaves here have similar names.
For example annotation, set annotation, set annotation or or document.
Document Document format or here you can see that all the words end with E. MPL, which stands for implementation.
But The thing is that this is exactly this kind of group or cluster that we don't want to get becausw.
For example, this word implementation should be somewhere else, should not be together with session implementation or Ajit adjective implementation, cause these are completely different concepts.
So that's why in Latino it is possible to include or to exclude different kinds of information.
So, and if we include another type of structural information, for example, this, this is now the semantic space where we included only the type reference structural information.
So this is now a different kind of information.
You can see that the space is different, it has less less obvious islands.
But the instances are more scattered, and if we now.
Create 8.
First level concepts in the same way as we did before.
You will see that these concepts are different, are completely different.
Let's see what happens.
OK, so now we have again we have 8 first level concepts.
And you can see that for example.
Now the the things that are grouped together are actually, so this makes much more sense.
So for example, here we have a concept dealing with annotations.
Here we here for example, let me see here.
We have a concept dealing with ontologies.
Here we have.
What else?
Here we have a concept dealing with with word, net and so on.
So this is now completely different.
Outcome.
So it is very important which which types of information we include and which types, which information we exclude from this process.
Um?
And so basically, that is what Latino is meant for.
It is meant to help the user to decide which types of information are going to produce the final ontology.
OK, now I will now say a few words about this whole case study.
It is about inclusion dependencies.
It's a bit different than the gate case study.
So inclusion dependencies are basically.
And inclusion dependency is when a set of database table condiments is included partially or fully in another database table.
So discovery of this inclusion dependencies is very important for information integration.
An the fact is that the solve databases contain inclusion dependencies and we think Latino and onto Jane can help detect those.
Um?
So what we did is.
We got the the database at least a sample of it and the Latino setting was as follows.
So the instances where comments so were table columns.
The documents were simply concatenated values in this columns and we define several relations between these instances.
One was the cosine similarity between documents.
Another one was similarity similarity between sets of values.
So we treated each column and as being a set of values, and then we computed the Jakarta similarity between the two sets and also some alternative we made up.
This alternative similarity measure, and we also included this edit distance between column names.
So this is now.
The semantic space of.
Of cosine similarity between column and columns.
And if we zoom in to this area, we probably cannot read this, but.
It is possible to see that these are columns dealing with vendor codes.
These are some other codes like catch codes, and these are some other comments, but this group here they are.
They are highly.
This is highly likely to be inclusion dependencies.
So we can show I can show you something else.
So what is possible is to arrange the pairs of columns according to the similar similarity between them.
And for example, if we look at this one, this particular pair of columns which are from completely different tables.
And these are these are these actual columns.

We can see that this code F6117 appears in both of them and also this code 198 appears here as well and that's why the similarity is high and this is most most likely to be valuable information for inclusion dependency detection.
OK, so this was basically it.
What are the plans that?
Further, plans for Latino, we hope that Latino will become a recognized open source architecture for text mining and link analysis.
We plan to build a user community by putting up a website, training, promotion and so on.
So everything that is needed, we need applications.
We need applications in case studies on the project in other projects outside the context of European projects and maybe even try to compete in some data mining contests.
And for the future work we plan to implement a visualization tool similar similar to the one integrated in on to gain.

But this will help to set the weights or or to decide the user which types of information to include in the process in which type to exclude regarding what the task, what did the task of what the task to be solved is.
We need to perform the evaluation.
Basically we can we need to show that we can solve problems which are introduced by case studies.
Better if we use Latino methodology rather than just simply using standard text mining techniques.
And of course we will continue the development of Latino S as needed.
So this is basically it.
And thank you for your attention.
